EACS 3.title: Introduction to Asian Religious Traditions
EACS 3.description: An introduction to the basic texts, institutions, and practices of the religious traditions of South Asia and East Asia.

EACS 4A.title: East Asian Traditions: Pre-modern
EACS 4A.description: An introduction to the social structures, institutions, systems of thought and belief, and the arts and entertainments of China and Japan during the  pre-modern period.

EACS 4B.title: East Asian Traditions: Modern
EACS 4B.description: An introduction to the study of China and Japan in modern times, including the process of modernization, intellectual and political movements,    national identity, literature and the arts, and popular culture.

EACS 5.title: Introduction to Buddhism
EACS 5.description: The historical and cross-cultural exploration of Buddhism through the  examination of basic texts, institutions, and practices of diverse   Buddhist traditions.

EACS 20.title: Nature: East Asian Views
EACS 20.description: An introduction to the ways in which Chinese and Japanese cultures have conceptualized nature and humankind's place in it.

EACS 21.title: Zen Buddhism
EACS 21.description: An introduction to the history and texts of the major lineages of Ch`an  Buddhism in China and Zen Buddhism in Japan.

EACS 30.title: Tourism in East Asia
EACS 30.description: Surveys the historical, cultural, and economic significance of tourists destinations in South Korea, China, and Japan. Using case studies ranging from temples, museums, monuments and theme parks, course analyzes how selected "images/myths" of East Asia have been invented, manipulated, and propagated in the commodification of culture and heritage.

EACS 47.title: Introduction to Daoism
EACS 47.description: A study of the classical sources of Daoism, followed by a consideration of the varieties of religious practice which developed from those sources.

EACS 74.title: The Western Discovery of Buddhism
EACS 74.description: Survey of the "discovery" and the study of Buddhism by Westerners from antiquity to the present, with special emphasis on the modern era. We will explore the mutual impact of Buddhism and Western modern culture.

EACS 80.title: Chinese Civilization
EACS 80.description: A survey of the history of Chinese civilization from 2,000 BCE to the present, focusing on the origins and later development of political, social, economic, philosophical, religious, and cultural traditions.

EACS 85.title: Modern China: An Introduction
EACS 85.description: The extraordinary changes that we are witnessing in today's China are the focus of fascination, anxiety, and confusion- sometimes all at once - both inside and outside of China. Though seemingly sudden, these changes are actually deeply rooted in Chinese history. This course is designed for students who are interested in understanding the connections between contemporary China and the recent Chinese past.

EACS 99.title: Independent Study in Asian Studies
EACS 99.comments: Students must have a cumulative 3.0 for the proceeding 1 quarter(s).   Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA. Limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
EACS 99.description: Introduction to independent research in Asian Studies.  Topic and content  are decided by the supervising Professor in the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultural Studies.

EACS 99RA.title: Independent Research Assistance on Asia
EACS 99RA.comments: Students must have a cumulative 3.0 for the proceeding 1 quarter(s).   Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA. Limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
EACS 99RA.description: Research details are decided by the supervising Professor in the   Department of East Asian Languages and Cultural Studies.

EACS 103A.title: Anthropology of China
EACS 103A.description: This course adopts an anthropological approach to contemporary China through ethnographic research. Topics include: Maoist society, rural life, migrant workers, gender and sexuality, media culture, youth culture, the urban work unit, from Maoist class-status system to capitalist class structure.

EACS 103B.title: Anthropology of Japan
EACS 103B.prereq_description: upper division standing or instructor approval
EACS 103B.description: This course examines Japan as depicted in contemporary ethnography. We consider how Japan has been imagined as a distinct culture by exploring gender, religion, family structures, the education system, the environment, management of difference, globalization and domestication, immigration, and modernization.

EACS 103C.title: Anthropology of Contemporary Korea
EACS 103C.comments: Students who have completed KOR 82 should not enroll in EACS 103C.
EACS 103C.description: This course is an introduction to contemporary Korea covering the major societal transformations since the Korean War. Topics include nationalism, the creation of national symbols and racial identity, family, marriage, consumption, television dramas, globalization, tourism, and new Korean Wave.

EACS 109A.title: Imagined China
EACS 109A.description: Is China really a timeless land of mystical wisdom, profound spiritualities, and ancient traditions? This class examines the Western misrepresentations of China as the eternal "Other" derived from orientalist, colonial, or other misreadings of the Middle Kingdom. Historical accounts  are considered against more recent critical perspectives.

EACS 109B.title: Christianity, Judaism, and Islam in China
EACS 109B.description: Examines Christian, Jewish, and Muslim communities in the Middle Kingdom from 500 to the present day, debunking the myth of a closed and insular China.

EACS 128.description: What can ancient religious traditions do for environmental protection?  This class examines doctrinal examples, both potential and actual, of religious environmentalism in China, India, Japan, and the U.S.:  with Buddhism, Daoism, Hinduism, Shinto, and Protestantism.

EACS 130.title: Tourism in East Asia
EACS 130.description: Investigates historical, cultural, and commercial agendas of heritage sites in South Korea, China, and Japan. Using case studies of ancient cities, landmarks, religions, and festivals, it analyzes the intertwined relationship between the heritage industry, preservation goals, developmental agendas, and the promotion of "authentic" experience and "national" landscapes.

EACS 131.title: Global East Asia
EACS 131.description: Offers an overview of theories about migration and globalization, coupled with the case studies from contemporary East Asia. Students investigate diverse transnational issues in and from this region, including ethnicity, nationalism, kinship, homeland, and colonialism.

EACS 134A.title: Buddhist Art
EACS 134A.description: A survey of selected forms of Indian, Chinese, and Japanese Buddhist art. Emphasis on Buddhist sculpture and Zen painting. Exploration of the correlation of religious values and art, transformation and adaptation of artistic traditions from one culture to another.

EACS 136.title: Children at War
EACS 136.description: The intersections of childhood, war, and play in Asia and other societies around the globe, from the late nineteenth century to today. Brings together studies of children and childhood with studies of war and peace.

EACS 140.title: Indigenous Movements in Asia
EACS 140.comments: Not open to students who have completed Japan 166.  Same course as ANTH 191.
EACS 140.description: Examines the emergence of indigenous peoples as a new kind of political community in Asia.  Reading across ethnographic, historical, and politic-legal perspectives, we will explore the material and symbolic benefits of claiming to be indigenous in non-western contexts.

EACS 141.title: Environmental Justice in Asia
EACS 141.description: Applies environmental justice, a tool for addressing social and    ethnic/racial inequality in environmental conditions, to analysis of   Asia. Contrasts mainstream environmental and sustainability models with  the justice-based approach to analyze how local communities devise   solutions for environmental crises.

EACS 142.title: Literary Adaptation in East Asia
EACS 142.description: Explores literary adaptation and intertextuality in East Asia through primary texts and readings from critical theory. Among the texts considered are traditional poetry, The Tale of Genji, Chinese "strange tales" and representations of history and literature in film.

EACS 147T.title: Introduction to Daoism
EACS 147T.description: A study of the classical sources of Daoism, followed by a consideration of the varieties of religious practice which developed from those sources.

EACS 150.title: Gender and Sexuality in Asian Modernities
EACS 150.prereq_description: Upper division standing or prior approval of the instructor
EACS 150.description: Transformations in gender and sexuality in modern China, Korea, India, Taiwan, Thailand, Singapore, and Japan. Topics include: family and kinship; role of the state; mass media; Asian nationalisms; gendered division of labor; queer cultures; and the commercialization of sex.

EACS 152.title: Ethnographic Research Methods: Ethics and Engagement
EACS 152.description: Interrogation of ethnographic research, its development and its ethical implications. Weighing approaches such as participatory action research, engaged and collaborative research, and decolonized methodologies. Students will develop projects based on a critical reading of these models.

EACS 156A.title: Anthropology of Religion
EACS 156A.description: Anthropological studies of religious practice, including theories of religion. Topics include: ritual and symbolism, religion and economy, religion and political power, gender and religion, religion and media, and globalization of religion. Students will undertake a mini-ethnographic project.

EACS 164B.title: Buddhist Traditions in East Asia
EACS 164B.description: A consideration of the Buddhist tradition and its evolution in China, with emphasis on the changes which Buddhism underwent in its encounter with Chinese traditions and historical circumstances.

EACS 165.title: East Asian Buddhist Poetry
EACS 165.description: Introduces Buddhist poetry of China, Japan, and Korea. Emphasizes the diversity of literary encounters with the teachings and practices of Buddhism. Topics include Hanshan, Basho, Zen koans, Gary Snyder, and monastery cats.

EACS 166.title: The Modern Girl Around the World
EACS 166.description: Examines the Modern Girl as a historical phenomenon of the early twentieth century from the combined perspective of global history and gender history.

EACS 171.title: Buddhism and Local Cults in Asia
EACS 171.prereq_description: One lower division or upper division course on Buddhism, or prior approval of the instructor
EACS 171.description: This course examines the multiple ways in which various Buddhist     traditions have interacted with "local" cults in various parts of Asia   (including China, Tibet, Japan, Burma, and Thailand). We will discuss  issues of localization and translocalization as important religious    phenomena.

EACS 176.title: Buddhist Political Thought and Institutions
EACS 176.prereq_description: upper division standing or instructor approval
EACS 176.description: Buddhist political theories and practices in various Asian countries from antiquity to the present, with special emphasis on ideas of kinship and republicanism, state-formation process, cultural identity, and the interactions with other religions.

EACS 179.title: Visual Culture of Buddhism
EACS 179.prereq_description: Upper division standing or instructor approval
EACS 179.description: This course explores the rich world of Buddhist visual culture, ranging from meditation to addressing the use of painted images in public performances. It focuses on sacred images, their rituals, and theories of representation behind their creation and use.

EACS 180.title: Visualizing Asia: Photography, Travel and Destination Marketing
EACS 180.description: Surveys the historical, artistic and commercial origins of travel media on Asia. Using case studies of iconic landmarks, it traces the impact of visual culture in the making and marketing of "must-  see" destinations in China, Japan and Korea.

EACS 181AAZZ.title: Special Topics in East Asian Studies
EACS 181AAZZ.description: Special topics in East Asian Studies. Course content varies.

EACS 185.title: Translation in Theory and Practice
EACS 185.description: A consideration of twentieth century thinking about language and the function of translation with readings from Benjamin, Derrida, Steiner, Borges. A translation from Chinese or Japanese (or other language) into English is required.

EACS 186.title: The Invention of Tradition in Contemporary East Asia
EACS 186.description: Analyzes the formation of national cultural properties classification systems, preservation laws, heritage institutions, collections of museum objects, worlds' fairs, and the management of heritage destinations in East Asia.

EACS 196.title: Internship
EACS 196.description: These internships allow students to collaborate with philanthropic and non-profit organizations, nationally and globally. Working digitally or on-site with the organization, students learn about practical implications of a degree in East Asian Languages and Cultural Studies and in the Humanities more generally. Students also have the opportunity to utilize their knowledge of technology and of foreign languages and cultures (intercultural communication, translation, etc.). While helping to make the world a better place, students gain valuable experience that can be applied to their chosen career after graduation.

EACS 197.title: Senior Honors Project
EACS 197.prereq_description: Open to EACS seniors only and prior approval of instructor
EACS 197.comments: Students must have a 3.0 overall GPA and a 3.5 GPA in the major.
EACS 197.description: An independent study project (1-2 quarters) directed by a faculty member with a carefully chosen topic and bibliography which will result in a  documented project or a senior thesis.

EACS 199.title: Independent Study in Asian Studies
EACS 199.prereq_description: Upper division standing; completion of 2 upper division EACS courses; at
EACS 199.comments: Students must have 3.0 GPA overall. Limit of 5 units/quarter and 30    units overall of any independent studies.
EACS 199.description: Independent Study under the supervision of a faculty member.

EACS 200AS.title: Great Books in East Asian History
EACS 200AS.description: A general examination preparation course, designed to introduce the  key historiography of East Asian History. Students read a series of  monographs and scholarly articles, ranging from ancient to contemporary  time. Readings surround themes of modernity, power, political history; social history; micro-  history; legal history; gender history; oral   history; and close textual reading and discursive analysis.

EACS 200XZ.title: Historical Literature: Asia
EACS 200XZ.description: A reading course in a general area of history, specifically designed to prepare M.A. candidates for their comprehensive examination fields, but also appropriate for Ph.D. students seeking broad preparation. Introduces the student to the sources, historiography, and general literature of the field in question.

EACS 201AS.title: Advanced Historical Literature
EACS 201AS.comments: Same course as History 201AS. May be taken more than once. Open to both MA and Ph.D. candidates. Usually offered quarterly.
EACS 201AS.description: A reading course in a field of the professor's specialty. Introduces the student to the sources and literature of the field in question. Written work as prescribed by the instructor.

EACS 212.title: Canon Formation, Periodization, and Disciplinarity in East Asian Studies
EACS 212.description: An analysis of classical, medieval, and modern sets of "canons" including  myth historiography, literature and the arts, with a view to question the  way they were mutually distinguished (disciplinary) and changed through  time (periodization) recognizing both internal conceptions and external  influences.

EACS 215.title: Topics in East Asian Cultural Studies
EACS 215.description: As a forum for the practice of discussion, critique, and writing, this seminar takes up broad topics within the study of East Asian cultures in an interdisciplinary manner.

EACS 218.title: The Art and Theory of Translation
EACS 218.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
EACS 218.description: An introduction to the literature of translation studies and practice in translation from principally, Chinese and Japanese. Students are encouraged to explore the extent to which translation theory can be usefully (artfully?) applied to translations in progress.

EACS 228.title: Religious Environmentalism in the Anthropocene
EACS 228.description: What can ancient religious traditions do for environmental protection?  This class examines doctrinal potentials and actual examples of religious environmentalism in China, India, Japan, and the U.S.:  with Buddhism, Daoism, Hinduism, Shinto, and Protestantism.

EACS 241.title: Environmental Justice in Asia
EACS 241.description: Applies environmental justice, a tool for addressing social and ethnic/racial inequality in environmental conditions, to analysis of Asia. Contrasts mainstream environmental and sustainability models with the justice-based approach to analyze how local communities devise solutions for environmental crises.

EACS 242.title: Literary Adaptation in East Asia
EACS 242.description: Explores literary adaptation and intertextuality in East Asia through primary texts and readings from critical theory. Among the texts considered are traditional poetry, The Tale of Genji, Chinese "strange tales," and representations of history and literature in film.

EACS 252.title: Ethnographic Research Methods: Ethics and Engagement
EACS 252.comments:
Concurrently offered with EACS 152. Concurrent with EACS 152. Graduate students will write a longer final research paper, hold additional meetings with the instructor, be required to go through the Human Subjects Review process for their research project, and give oral presentation of their research findings (15 minutes) during course meeting times.
Repeat Comments: Topics vary; may be repeated for credit.
EACS 252.description: Interrogation of ethnographic research, its development and its ethical implications. Weighing approaches such as participatory action research, engaged and collaborative research, and decolonized methodologies, students will develop projects based on a critical reading of these models.

EACS 257.title: Seminar in Buddhist Studies
EACS 257.description: Historical, philosophical, methodological, and/or bibliographical analysis of different aspects of Buddhism or of selected areas in the study of Buddhism.

EACS 260.title: Methods, Politics, and Epistemology: Doing Ethnography in Asia
EACS 260.description: This seminar aims to engage the practice of ethnography as a critically  reflective exercise. The course introduces key issues in the genealogy,  practice, epistemology, and the politics of ethnography as a research  method with focus on research in Asian contexts.  Target Audience:   Graduate students interested in gaining hands-on knowledge of research methodology.

EACS 265.title: East Asian Buddhist Poetry
EACS 265.comments: Concurrently offered with EACS 165 & C LIT 165.

EACS 268.title: Religion, Modernity, Asia
EACS 268.description: Explores how modernity transformed ritualized Asian monarchical states into new nation-states.  Premodern ritual states; colonialism and postcolonialism; traditional culture, modernism, nationalism; religious civil societies; secularization; changing relations between state and religion; religious globalization. Emphasis on China, but  also Japan, India, and other Asian polities.

EACS 271.title: Buddhism and Local Cults in Asia
EACS 271.comments: Concurrent with EACS 171.  Graduate students will have additional readings specified in the syllabus and an additional research paper.
EACS 271.description: This course examines the multiple ways in which various Buddhist traditions have interacted with "local" cults in various parts of Asia (including China, Tibet, Japan, Burma, and Thailand). We will discuss issues of localization and translocalization as important religious phenomena.

EACS 276.title: Buddhist Political Thought and Institutions
EACS 276.comments: Concurrent with EACS 176.  Graduate students will have additional readings specified in the syllabus and an additional research paper.
EACS 276.description: Buddhist political theories and practices in various Asian countries   from antiquity to the present, with special emphasis on ideas of kingship  and republicanism, state-formation process, cultural identity, and the   interactions with other religions.

EACS 278.title: Buddhist Geography
EACS 278.description: This course analyzes Buddhist ideas about the external world: the structure of the universe, world geography and Buddhist world maps, geopolitical considerations (in particular, the relations between regional forms of Buddhism and India), and local constructs of sacred space.

EACS 279.title: Visual Culture of Buddhism
EACS 279.comments: Concurrent with EACS 179.  Graduate students will have additional readings specified in the syllabus and an additional research paper.
EACS 279.description: This course explores the rich world of Buddhist visual culture, ranging from meditation to addressing the use of painted images in public performances. It focuses on sacred images, their rituals, and theories of representation behind their creation and use.

EACS 292AAZZ.title: Special Topics
EACS 292AAZZ.description: Seminar in special areas of interest in East Asian cultural studies.   Specific course titles and topics to be announced by the department each quarter offered.  Course content will vary.

EACS 296.title: Internship
EACS 296.description: These internships allow students to collaborate with philanthropic and non-profit organizations, nationally and globally. Working digitally or on site with the organization, students learn about practical implications of a degree in Religious Studies and in the Humanities more generally. They also have the opportunity to utilize their knowledge of foreign languages and technology. While helping to make the world a better place, students gain valuable experience that can be applied to their chosen career after graduation.

EACS 500.title: Laboratory for Teaching Assistants
EACS 500.comments: These units do not count toward the graduate degree.
EACS 500.description: Subject-oriented, designed to relate directly to the teaching of a particular course in progress, to improve the skills and effectiveness of the department's teaching assistants.

EACS 596.title: Directed Reading and Research
EACS 596.comments:
Misc: Letter grade; minimum of two units per quarter.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit.

EACS 597.title: Preparation for Comprehensive/Qualifying Examinations
EACS 597.comments:
No unit credit allowed toward degree.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit.
EACS 597.description: Preparation for MA comprehensive examinations and/or PhD qualifying    examinations.

EACS 598.title: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
EACS 598.comments:
Maximum of 12 units total. No unit credit allowed toward master's degree.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit.
EACS 598.description: Research, preparation, and writing of the master's thesis.
